body:
Hi @jaraco,

> Now tests pass, but all of the deprecation warnings (from the dependencies) are suppressed. That wasn't what I'd intended by setting the project to error on warnings.

Indeed. When we introduced the warnings plugin a few versions back we had some serious regressions, so this time around I decided to be really conservative to minimize disruption.

The unittest module only [changes the warnings filters to diplay deprecations](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/db1a80e97aa7217c561fb3627f70be1882de9534/Lib/unittest/runner.py#L167) if [sys.warnoptions](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/db1a80e97aa7217c561fb3627f70be1882de9534/Lib/unittest/main.py#L88) is set (usually by `PYTHONWARNINGS`). I decided to go with the same route with our warnings plugin:

https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/58aa4f91f5e124921eba24baef6c62db5d4eb279/src/_pytest/warnings.py#L72-L90

So basically we only install the filters *if* the user did not specify any filter configuration themselves, either using pytest's mechanisms or python's own `PYTHONWARNINGS`.

But I agree with you that this is not ideal, because as you point out any customization effectively silences deprecation warnings again.

I believe that for `3.9` we can install the deprecation filters before all other filters, right after `catch_warnings()` in the previous snippet. This shows deprecations by default, but any other filter that comes after it will take precedence.
Wonderful. Yes, I completely understand the desire to be cautious... and I concur with your assessment and plan. Most importantly, thank you for all the time and effort you put into this project.

issue.title: Show deprecation warnings even if filters are customized

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing
